title: Do students actually transfer from community colleges to Ivy League universities? - Quora

response.answer_text: Although I did not transfer from a community college my path was similar. I began my college career at SUNY Oneonta - a middle-tier New York State funded institutions for those who do not know. My high school performance was less than average (85/100 average with only 1 AP courses). To give some perspective on how average I was, I come from a well-off school district where more than half of my graduating class of 300 were inducted into the National Honors Society – I was not. Point being, it was not that hard to do well at my high school and even a little effort paid off; apparently I wasn’t willing to make that effort. When I arrived at college and realized I was voluntarily paying for my education I knew I needed to make a drastic change. I then made the decision to completely dedicate myself to my own education. At college I decide the best way to make this change was to throw myself into what I believed were the hardest courses I could take and see what happened (would not always recommended this method but it worked out in my case) . So, I took mostly STEM classes including physics, calculus, chemistry and computer programming. I ended up with decently high grades (3.9 GPA) at the end of my two years through a fair amount of studying and stress. I then decided I wanted better for myself, so I applied to some above average engineering programs including UVA and Columbia as well as some other reputable SUNY programs. Long story short, I got into every school I applied to except Columbia (no surprise there). It has been my experience that what ultimately matters most is the effort you put into your time at your college. If you show yourself to be capable and enthusiastic, college admissions will recognize that. To answer your question: yes, it is certainly possible to transfer to top-tier institution from any college around the world. At least that is true legally speaking (do not quote me on that). Perhaps some universities might secretly black-list some schools from having transfer students from that institution but that is fairly unlikely. Regardless, these things are completely out our control so there is no use in wasting our energy thinking about them. That being said, it is naive to think that the college you apply from will have no influence in the admissions process. Of course, it is more likely for an admissions officer at Harvard to trust the achievements of a Princeton student than one a mid-tier school such as the one I transferred from. You should not let this discourage you though. These schools know better than anyone that sometimes the students these schools do accept are not always quite what they thought they would be and the talent they are looking for can come from anywhere. I apologize for rambling and divulging my life story on here but I hope it may have helped and inspired some - best of luck to you and all others looking for advice!

Yes, it happens, though it's probably very rare. I can confirm it happens because I know a person who did it—but only one. I think it's rare because community colleges typically have transfer agreements with state/public universities, where the associate's degree is structured to cover some or all of the state's 4-year college general requirements, such as electives or college writing courses. Some states (like Washington, where I went to college) allocate some 4-year college transfer slots for students transferring out of community colleges. I don't know of any private schools with similar arrangements. Public schools also have different incentives and obligations. They're funded by taxpayer money; they aim to educate state students first, and many state students come through community colleges for economic and other reasons. They also tend to have tighter budgets (no Harvard endowments here!) so the prospect of graduating a student in two fewer years is appealing. Unlike Ivy League schools, these state schools and their governing organizations have had a hand in planning community college degree programs, so they're more confident about what a community college graduate will know, the rigor of their community college coursework, etc. But if you consider top universities instead of just Ivy League universities, community college transfers become more common because many top universities are state schools, including:  The U California schools, esp. Berkeley and Los Angeles.University of VirginiaUniversity of MichiganUniversity of WashingtonUniversity of WisconsinUniversity of North Carolina(That list is obviously not exhaustive.) Disclosure: I completed an associate's degree at North Seattle Community College before transferring to and graduating from UW.

It's very rare, but possible. I transferred from a community college to Caltech, which is at least as selective as most of the Ivies. There were many factors I had going for me, and I can list some of those if you like. But I suspect that the best way that I was able to differentiate myself was through recommendation letters from my professors. UPDATE: Here's some of the things I could brag about on my application.1) I started calculus in community college when I was 14, and the next year I graduated high school early and took all of my classes there. I aced all of the hardest math and physics class available, despite taking 16-18 units every term. I had a single B on my transcript, from my first English class. 2) Caltech requires transfer exams in math and physics. I aced the math exam easily; the physics exam was harder and longer, so I couldn't even finish it. But then I hadn't yet finished taking E&M when I applied, so they may have allowed for that. 3) I participated in the AMATYC math contest, a national contest for community college students. In my last year, I finished 8th overall in the country. 4) I spent a year in our student government, as a senator for the math division. 5) I worked as a tutor for Calculus II for a year. 6) But I think the most important of all was that I went above and beyond what was required in several of my classes, and then asked those professors for recommendations. In math, I would do challenge problems on the side, or search for my own proofs, and share what I found with my professors. Looking back, nothing I discovered was that special. But the fact that I at least tried showed my passion for math. In one of my programming classes, our final project was to write our own game. I added all kinds of new features to it, long after I could have called it done. It's still my favorite coding project I've ever worked on, and my professor was very impressed. The bottom line is, Caltech is looking for people who will devote themselves to math and science. From when I first visited, I knew I was a perfect match, and I made sure that everyone around me could see that too.

Of the eight Ivy league colleges (which is an athletic league) Harvard takes less than three CC transfers per year and Yale only takes a total of 24 (total) and the CCs are a small percentage. Princeton takes No transfers. Cornell takes a lot of transfers each year and 28% of those are CC grads.   See:Harvard Lags in Community College Recruitment | News | The Harvard CrimsonandGetting into elite universities - through community colleges Remember, at Cornell it is only the College of Arts and Sciences that is considered "Ivy League".  Indeed, two of the many colleges at Cornell are NY State public colleges........   (bet you didn't know that...) And Cornell Loves to stack its athletic teams with CC transfers.  Indeed Bruce Arena was a CC transfer into Cornell and became the soccer goalie for Cornell.  (If you don't know who Bruce Arena is, do Not pass Go and do Not transfer to an Ivy League college.....) So, if you graduated from a CC and are a star athlete plus a good student then you may be able to punch your ticket to Cornell.     However, for you non-athletes, it is easier to get into the Ivy League as a freshman than as a CC transfer. CC graduates are supposed to immediately pass Go, collect financial aid, and start as a Junior at their state's flagship public university.    Then they attend an Ivy League college as a graduate student working on a thesis and paying Nothing.   Win-Win. All the best.

They Ivies are selecting “exceptional” candidates to admit to their school. So, theoretically, it is possible - BUT, you would need a good “reason why” you were at a community school - since they get most of their applicants through 1st year applications. Transfers are possible (but few, depending on the school) but why did you not apply to the Ivies as a 1st year? What were you doing that didn’t allow you to apply as a freshman? Were you training for the US Olympics? Were you re-building a refugee camp somewhere? What the heck was going on that you waited a couple of years and want to transfer? How were you going to a community college while you were doing whatever you were doing ? These are just obvious admissions questions. (Most Ivies allow deferrals and gap years - so if admitted as a freshman, they would let your defer a year or two if you had something else you needed to finish up or explore, not a problem.) I guess, in short, you have a lot of explaining to do to convince them that your are “exceptional” (some define as test scores/GPA, others have remarkable personal achievements, or extreme hardships, that limited your ability to apply to colleges). Unless you are “world class” at something (even something unusual), then, you better have near- perfect GPA’s/Test scores if you are going to go down the “hardship” path. Getting accepted to an Ivy is a huge accomplishment and I always tell students to “try” if that’s what they really want, but be realistic that the odds are not in your favor - unless your can point to something “exceptional” that is attractive to admissions to add to their student body. Average isn’t going to cut it. So, you will have to assess this yourself and be able to write a compelling essay to explain why you are worthy of admissions. -Best o Luck!

They do (except Princeton)! Couple things to keep in mind. It will be an uphill battle. Getting into the Ivy League is always difficult, and getting in via the transfer process is no different. Ensuring that your application is stocked full of great college grades, high test scores, and some interesting extracurricular opportunities can assist with this endeavor, so be sure you’re able to compete with the best for the few spots available.Some Ivies are more friendly to CC transfer applicants than others. Harvard and Yale for example have less than 10 cc transfer spots together. Princeton has none. However, Cornell alone has nearly 160. Columbia and UPenn are very challenging to get into, but have specialized programs that are geared towards students who took a year off from their education and wish to rejoin academics. (Look up Columbia’s School of General Studies and Penn’s liberal and professional studies program).As a side-note I have personally met someone in Columbia’s School of General Studies program, he had absolutely nothing but glowing recommendations for the program (another friend of mine was considering that program), and deeply encouraged any community college students to give it a serious consideration.

I've personally met three individuals who transferred to ivies from community college (1 Yale, 2 Cornell). Stanford is not in the ivy-league division, but I know 3 folks who transferred there from my community college. Believe it or not, it not uncommon to transfer to any ivy or a high caliber university from another university or community college, it just requires a lot of work, strong grades, planning and research to make sure you're taking the appropriate transferrable courses, good letters of recommendations and a strong personal statement essays. Articles of transfer students success stories: SAN MARCOS: Palomar graduate John Aragon heads to YaleTransfer Students' StanfordHarvard Lags in Community College Recruitment | News | The Harvard CrimsonFrom community college to the Ivy League - yes, it's possibleIf you're trying to transfer to CSU or UC (UC Berkeley, LA....etc) from a California community college and would like to find out what classes you need to take, look no further than ASSIST.org. A friend of mine who transferred to Cornell is in the process of making an online community for community college students hoping to transfer to four year universities.  About me: I attended City College of San Francisco before transferring to UC Berkeley with my twin brother.

Yes, it actually is possible. My cousin transferred from Foothill Community College to Columbia University. However, before he attended Foothill he graduated high school in America early, and went to school at a madrasa in South Africa for 4 years. Because of this, he was able to put together a brilliant and compelling application. He also, himself, is absolutely exceptional. He has a passion for understanding the world and knows 5 different languages. He also scored very high on the SAT’s. Everyone has their own unique circumstances, but it is possible, and you should definitely try! Additionally, Princeton University is the only Ivy League that does not allow transfer students, but Cornell University is known to be a relatively easy Ivy school to transfer into. I am not entirely too sure, but I assume that transferring to Cornell is probably as difficult as transferring to UCLA or UC Berkeley. I know a lot of people that transfer to Cornell. There are also a lot of great school’s that are not a part of the Ivy League, like Stanford University. Stanford actually prefers to admit community college transfer students over university transfer students into their undergraduate school. So definitely give Stanford a try too! Good luck on your academic journey!

If they don’t, then Cornell made a really big mistake admitting me, haha. I went to community college for two years and got an Associate’s, then transferred to Cornell. There’s actually a lot of transfers to Cornell, but as you may be able to guess, many, if not most of them, are from other 4-year colleges. But do you have to be a genius or a prodigy who could’ve gotten into an Ivy League school straight from high school? Absolutely not. I didn’t have a perfect 4.0 in community college. In high school, I got rejected from San Diego State because my grades were “not competitive enough” according to the admissions people there. It will take a lot of time though. There were many nights when I was writing an essay or doing work with extracurriculars and I would stay on campus until security officers would kick me and my friends out. It also helps to have a story, such as being a veteran or other unique things about myself. Good luck!

It’s rare but possible. The question is, what are you bringing forward? Also, why is the Ivy so important to you? Is is for a Bachelor’s per se, or it could it be for an Advanced degree? For a Bachelors’ if you have qualifying SAT’s, that helps. Also a compelling letter and LOR’s.What you might consider is transferring to a state/public school for your Bachelors, doing well, and doing well in your career for a few years. Then seek a Graduate degree in an Ivy. At that point, the overall picture changes. The Ivy is looking at you as a whole person. While you are in your career those few years you could take non-credit or certificate programs at the Ivy of your choice, which may help. Many such courses are available online. I do know of two people who received their education through the Military on a Bachelor’s level, served their Military term, were in a career for a couple of years and then both were accepted at Wharton for MBA’s and did very well. A Graduate admissions counselor theoretically looks at a broader picture of you than an Undergrad admissions counselor does.

When my son and I were visiting MIT after he was accepted, I met a student who had first attended a community college in New England and then transferred to MIT. MIT is a Tier I college, which means it’s at the same general level as the so-called Ivy League colleges. Some colleges may not accept students with any prior college experience other than dual credit taken during high school. Even at the Tier 1 colleges who do accept transfer students, the percentage of accepted students who are transfer students tends to be very small at such colleges compared to the number of accepted students who graduated from high school and then went directly to the Ivy League or Tier 1 college without first taking community college courses.

Yes, I am one. I went to Butte Community College in Oroville, CA, then on to Columbia University in NYC, then finished up with grad school at Syracuse University in upstate NY. Columbia is the best option for transfer students as they have the School of General Studies, made for transfer students really. It was initially set up to accommodate WWII vets in the mid 1940’s. The school is still very Veteran friendly to this day (I am a Vet) but looks for all sorts of interesting folks to fill the ranks of GS. Princeton is trying to get something similar going, and I know a couple folks that went to Yale from a CC. The most difficult is probably Harvard, Cornell is good too, they recruited me prior to me choosing Columbia. Here is a link that tells a bit about GS at Columbia: Columbia University School of General Studies - Wikipedia Columbia GS | School of General Studies | Columbia University in the City of New York Hope this helps, and good luck!

It IS possible for a community college student to transfer to a very competitive university. I’m a community college faculty member, and I’ve had Engineering students transfer to Cornell, Berkeley, and Georgia Tech. Another former student took all the science courses offered at my college, and spent her summers doing research with our biology and chemistry faculty. She applied to nine very competitive universities (including Berkeley) and was accepted into all nine. These students had near 4.00 GPAs on top of a host of impressive extra curricular activities. Not to diminish their accomplishments by any means, but in the interest of objectivity, I don’t know whether attending community college in Wyoming factored into the admission. And in case anyone is wondering about the issue of ethnic heritage (and hesitates to to bring it up) one is Caucasian, and three are international students from Asia. I know that this post doesn’t address the Ivies specifically, but I hope this is useful information.

Yes it is possible.  I am only familiar with the east coast, but this is happening more and more often as tuition in 4 year institutions continues to rise and community colleges become an affordable, sensible alternative for gen Ed courses.  Not only are Ivies accepting CC grads (I know Columbia and University of Pennsylvania do for sure, imagine others do as well) so are the smaller, excellent liberal arts colleges (Swarthmore, for example.). That being said, if the community college has an honors program the student should be in it, be a member of PTK honor society, show interesting outside activities and/or work experience - as you might imagine.  Also, the reputation of the community college is important. Look at the schools administrators came from as a hint about connections.  Good luck, truly hope it works out!  Oh, here is just one example of a good east coast community college and some successes they've had.  http://www.raritanval.edu/pstudents/transfersuccess.html

Cornell University, an Ivy League school, has State University of New York (SUNY) Colleges. SUNY also has two year colleges locally. Delhi-SUNY in Delhi, NY, is an example. Those two year colleges have worked with other Community Colleges, like Delhi and Schenectady Community College. SUNY credits are transferrable between the colleges, (not necessarily programs). If other requirements are met, it is possible to enter Cornell from an accredited community college in New York. Another New York Ivy League University, Brown, has an UG/G agreement with Susquehanna University in Selinsgrove, Pennsylvania. So, if accepted into that program, community college to a 4-year school to an Ivy League college is possible. Penn State (PSU), graduates have also went to Ivy League graduate schools, and they have smaller campuses around the Commonwealth similar to SUNY in New York. After degrees from PSU, I was at Cornell and PSU friend, Dan, completed his law degree at Harvard. So, additional ways of getting into the Ivy League are possible.

Yes, with caveats. Princeton doesn’t take transfer students at all. The others do, but some will only have a few openings to fill (Cornell takes more than the others), which makes them very competitive, but they will review an application from a community college student like they would any other transfer application. It’s even harder to transfer into most Ivy’s than it is to get in through the freshman admissions process, but I know of two students who successfully did so (neither, actually, to Cornell). A transfer applicant should cast a wider net than just the Ivys, but those with strong applications that are very interested in an Ivy shouldn’t feel discouraged from applying.

I would think - thus my opinion only and no facts - that the number of community college transfers is very very extremely small into Ivys. The ONLY reason I say this is when I was attending Notre Dame (77-81) there general policy was NO transfers (I do not know if it is now).  However, NO does not mean none since I was friends with a transfer student from Westpoint.  Seems he got tagged really well during mandatory boxing training and went into a seizure during his sophomore year.  Unfit for military service.  Thus he was accepted as a junior at Notre Dame.

All of them accept very few. I would expect that Penn and Columbia accept a slightly higher percentage from their own evening extension program, merely because they know the quality of the work, as well as the faculty. Had I answered this two days ago, I would have included Harvard’s extension school, but someone else wrote that that school is not as academically rigorous, and that Harvard is not likely to allow people to transfer from the extension school into the regular program. I don’t know whether this is true, but having read it, I feel that I should at least mention it.

Regardless what kind of bull crap some of these folks will say to you, your chances of transferring to elite colleges such as the Ivies or IvyPlus are slim to none. Mainly because: They have high application volumes, low acceptance rates, lower enrollment numbers and higher yields than state schools (which are the easiest to transfer to).Simply put: because they don’t need to!! Bottom line.Want to transfer to a good college? I recommend second/third tier private schools or flagship state schools. That’s your best bet. Or apply for graduate school at one of those colleges. Otherwise. Fuhgetuboutit!!

You need the same things as someone applying out of high school. You need to be getting top grades at your college, have top SAT or ACT scores, and extracurriculars that make sense given your career goals or are long time passions (not a random list of things you took up this year). A job that you've had for years is just as good as a club. You need to be taking the most challenging course series that your community college offers (if there is regular algebra and honors algebra, be in honors; if there is algebra I or accelerated algebra I/II, choose the accelerated). You need to be able to write well, and you need good recommendations (e.g. from a job, a research experience, or a current or recent instructor). Good luck! I love the community college system in the US and I think Ivy league takes it just as seriously as any high school, certainly.

When I was Dean of Science, Engineering, Health Sciences and Human Performance at Ocean County College in Toms River, New Jersey, we had 3 students in the sciences able to transfer to Cornell, Columbia and the University of Pennsylvania. They were outstanding students in every respect. Community Colleges have become a great way for students to begin college for reasonable costs and end up transferring to top notch universities to finish their bachelors degree.

Yes. I was considered at Stanford, but I could not afford tuition. I did not have a strong support system to help me — I was a single mother of two little girls. My dad and brothers live close to Berkeley and helped me a lot during my college years. Thus, the reason why I chose this college. I had a 4.0, strong college and community involvement, and was a champion cross country and track-and-field runner. Personally, I think my success in sports played a big part in the process.

I’m sure you can. I know you can get accepted into MIT from a community college, because my MIT interviewer told me that he did. And if you can get into MIT from a community college, you can probably get into one of the Ivies too. I’m sure the standards are pretty high, though. You would need to be extremely involved in both your college community and your physical living community to get into an Ivy from a community college. My personal recommendation would be to go to a state school from a community college, work hard there, and then go to graduate school at an Ivy.

Is it possible to transfer from a community college to an Ivy league school? In selecting a university to transfer to, a community college graduate should consider identifying a set of schools, reach (less likely), target (likely), and safety (close to sure thing). Keeping in mind that Ivy League schools are reach schools for all applicants, and that they take very few transfer students, go ahead and apply, but no bets. Instead, I suggest shooting for your state flagship university, which also should aligned with the CC to admit you directly as a junior. A safety school might be a lower ranked state college, again in your own state.

Yes, a lawyer i know, attended the local junior college for two years,transferred to Harvard and graduated in two years.hethen attended and graduated from Harvard law school. He was intelligent, ambitious and poor. He worked his way through junior college by working as a construction subcontractor. His academics and unusual background caught the attention of the Harvard admissions department.

It’s possible, but you need to look at each school’s tendency to do this, as some are more amenable than others.All of them take the overwhelming number of their applicants as 1st year entrants. You must also have a very good story behind why you didn’t just apply to your school of choice to begin with, and financial considerations are not generally considered to be a good excuse, nor, quite frankly, is a lack of self-confidence in your high school academic performance.

Transferring to an Ivy League or other similarly prestigious college is already hard enough as it is, and transferring from a community college may make that even more difficult. However, it is most certainly possible, and I’m sure it’s been done.
The ivies in general accept very few transfers period, typically a handful per year at each school ( Princeton takes 0). Columbia will take transfers into its School of General Studies.

A2A. Is it possible to transfer from a community college to an Ivy league school? Yes, it is possible especially if the Ivy is designed for transfer such as Cornell and to a lesser degree Penn. See Transfer Acceptance Rates at US News Top 50. The fact that you went to community college does not hinder you as much as other might think so. You will need to get As in your courses to be competitive.

It all depends on your community college results. Transfering from community colleges to universities is quite common but one has to have done very well at the community college. Ivy Leagues are no different. As I have said many times, talk with an administrator at the university of your choice to get the full scoop. In general this is very doable!
Not sure about community college, but I can tell you that Cornell accepts the most transfer students overall.  Hope that helps!

The question as stated has received many good answers. But some of them raise the question of why most Ivy League universities admit so few transfers and at least one, Princeton, none. The answer to that question would be that at the Ivy League colleges and the top small LAC colleges 90 percent or more of each class stays on and graduates. That leaves very few places for transfers.

Thanks for the A2A, Li. The Ivies may accept a small number of community college transfers — you’ll need to check the policy of each university. Princeton, for example, just recently reinstituted a transfer policy, but only admitted 13 students, including several from community colleges. Princeton offers admission to 13 students in reinstated transfer program

Dartmouth College has a significant amount of transfer students, including community college students every year. Dartmouth still has high standards, but has they say they're committed to invest in students who have the right stuff. Dartmouth College Give it try. Thanks for the A2A.
It happens all the time at Cornell. Since Cornell has land-grant component colleges, those colleges are obligated to admit in-state transfers from community colleges.
If you have a very good GPA as well as extra circulatory activities under your selves. But despite that it is still extremely hard to transfer.
Most of the Ivy league schools don't take any transfer students, but you would have to inquire at the particular school you are interested in.
Yes.
